chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect chronic pancreatitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Early diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is usually difficult and requires investigation and confirmation in secondary care.

  • Suspect chronic pancreatitis in any person with chronic or recurrent upper or generalized abdominal pain, particularly if they have a history or clinical features of alcohol misuse. 
    • For information on the assessment of hazardous and harmful drinking, and alcohol dependency, see the CKS topic on Alcohol - problem drinking.
  • If chronic pancreatitis is suspected:
    • Ask about the pain. The person may present with chronic pain, or report a history of recurrent episodes of acute pain, however pain can be absent in up to 20% of people regardless of the cause. Pain, when present:
      • Is typically deep, severe, and dull in the epigastric region. It may radiate to the back, or may be localized to the right or left upper quadrants.
      • May be intermittent, constant, or continuous, with superimposed acute flares.
      • May be relieved by sitting upright and leaning forward.
      • Is often precipitated by eating.
      • May be associated with nausea and vomiting.
    • Ask about other symptoms of chronic pancreatitis, including:
      • Bloating, abdominal cramps, and excessive flatus.
      • Weight loss.
      • Malnutrition.
      • Steatorrhoea (loose, greasy, foul-smelling stools that are difficult to flush away, and may cause faecal incontinence).
      • Diabetes mellitus and impaired glucose regulation.
  • Examine for typical signs of chronic pancreatitis which may include:
    • Signs of chronic liver disease (suggestive of chronic alcohol use).
    • Epigastric tenderness.
    • Jaundice, due to:
      • Concomitant liver disease.
      • Mechanical obstruction of the extrahepatic bile duct by a mass in the head of the pancreas, or a pseudocyst.
    • Abdominal distension due to a pseudocyst, pancreatic ascites, or pancreatic cancer.
    • Firm skin nodules due to disseminated fat necrosis (rare).
    • Shortness of breath due to fluid leaking from a ruptured duct or pseudocyst and tracking to the pleural space (rare).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
When to suspect chronic pancreatitis

  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in two review articles [Mayerle et al, 2013; BMJ, 2015].

Clinical features of chronic pancreatitis 

  • The information on the clinical features of chronic pancreatitis is taken from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Alcohol-use disorders: Diagnosis and clinical management of alcohol-related physical complications [NICE, 2010] and expert opinion in two review articles [Mayerle et al, 2013; BMJ, 2015].
